• Corviknight's fantastic typing makes it one of the best pivots in the metagame; it easily gets dangerous teammates such as Hydreigon, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult in.

  • Brave Bird: Brave Bird's damage output generally justifies the recoil.

  • Body Press: Body Press deals much more damage to Kingambit and Electric-types such as Rotom-W but makes Dragapult and Flutter Mane a problem.

  • Rocky Helmet: This lets Corviknight wear down physical threats more quickly while pivoting.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight's defensive typing is fantastic, so don't Terastallize too hastily and lose to more threats.

  • Dragon: Dragon and Fairy weaknesses are devastating, but in the late-game, resisting Electric and Fire can give Corviknight new win conditions against old foes such as Rotom-W.

  • Flying: Boosting Brave Bird's damage output is nice, but the secret to the Flying Tera type is that Corviknight will no longer be vulnerable to Fissure while it uses Roost.

  • Grass: Grass improves matchups against Rotom-W and Breloom significantly.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Corviknight stands out as one of the best choices around for a defensive Steel-type, thanks to recovery and Body Press.

  • Taunt: This lets Corviknight effectively shut down slower defensive Pokemon, such as Dondozo.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head helps Corviknight check Mimikyu more easily, especially if not running Rocky Helmet. It also prevents Corviknight from being walled by Flutter Mane and Dragapult.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight has a fantastic defensive typing, so only Terastallize if you need to win certain matchups, especially since it becomes vulnerable to Toxic.

  • Flying: A Flying Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing even when using Roost, making it a more reliable check to Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Body Press is easier to sweep with, as long as troublesome Fairy-types such as Mimikyu are removed.

  • Grass: Tera Grass Corviknight not only handles Rotom-W better, but can set up on Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

  • Dragon: A Dragon Tera type lets Corviknight resist common attacks aimed at it, such as Electric- and Fire-type attacks. However, the new weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon make this a reactive Terastallization.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: The passive damage from Rocky Helmet against Mimikyu gives Corviknight a much easier time using Taunt over Iron Head.

  • Leftovers: Corviknight tends to stick around, so Leftovers recovery makes sense over a Berry.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• With Bulk Up giving an Attack boost, Corviknight is free from having to use Body Press for good damage output.

  • Taunt: This is highly recommended for shutting down Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is chosen for both reliable damage output and hitting Fairy-types hard.

  • Power Trip: Power Trip takes several boosts to get powerful, but it's Corviknight's best shot at dealing decent damage to Gholdengo, being able to break its Substitute after Bulk Up. It also makes Corviknight a powerful Baton Pass recipient when using Espathra.

  • Covert Cloak: This makes Corviknight immune to Salt Cure's residual damage, making Corviknight a good check to Garganacl.

Tera Types

  • Remember that most of Corviknight's good Tera types leave it vulnerable to Toxic, so Terastallize carefully.

  • Dark: While it doesn't help Corviknight much defensively, a Dark Tera type lets it 2HKO 4 HP Gholdengo with Power Trip after one use of Bulk Up.

  • Flying: This Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing while using Roost, meaning Fissure users such as Dondozo are much easier to handle.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type boosts Iron Head and removes Corviknight's Electric weakness, at the cost of making it vulnerable to Earthquake.

  • Dragon: Once Fairy- and Dragon-types are out of the way, the Dragon Tera type allows Corviknight to get around Electric- and Fire-type attacks.

  • Grass-type: A Grass Tera type is Corviknight's best way of setting up on Breloom and handling Rotom-W.

Grimmsnarl.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• With Prankster and the movepool to use it, Grimmsnarl is one of the best dual screens setters, as it is useful for setting up dangerous sweepers such as Dragonite or Iron Valiant.

  • Parting Shot: Parting Shot is not only useful for dropping stats, but the pivoting action can let Grimmsnarl come in later to set up screens if it's in a bad matchup.

  • Thunder Wave: This is a reasonable alternative for crippling fast foes that may be problematic for sweeps.

  • Taunt: Taunt shuts down phazers and opposing Taunts that could stop the dual screens from being set up.

  • Spirit Break versus Foul Play: Hitting foes like Great Tusk and Roaring Moon makes Spirit Break a good offensive move. Alternatively, Foul Play is notable for breaking Gholdengo's Substitute and punishing physical setup sweepers.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Grimmsnarl should almost never Terastallize, since it's trying to support sweepers rather than deal serious damage on its own. Still, a Grass Tera type is a reasonable choice for blocking Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

Dragapult.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Dragapult's incredible Speed makes it a very effective hit-and-run attacker.

  • Phantom Force: This is risky due to the two turns making Dragapult vulnerable to Normal-types and surprise Terastallization, but lack of many strong Ghost-resistant foes makes Phantom Force an effective late-game cleaning move.

  • Shadow Ball: With a Naive nature, Shadow Ball is an easy way to 2HKO Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and incoming Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Dragon and Ghost: Terastallizing into either of Dragapult's STAB types makes it even more difficult to wall, with Ghost being notable for letting Dragapult use a less risky STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives a valuable Fairy-type resistance and is a more powerful tool against Steel-types at the cost of a Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dragon-type immunity can help win Tera wars against foes like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting vastly improves Dragapult's match-up against Kingambit and Choice Scarf Meowscarada.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band guarantees that Breloom is OHKOed through its Focus Sash with Dragon Darts.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Sucker Punch a less risky option.

  • Choice Scarf: This may seem like overkill, but Choice Scarf gives Dragapult the edge over Booster Energy users such as Iron Bundle, Roaring Moon, and Flutter Mane, and other Choice Scarf foes such Gholdengo.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Despite Dragapult's insane Speed stat, Dragon Dance insulates it from popular revenge killers such as Booster Energy Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, making it a great sweeper.

  • Phantom Force: Phantom Force's drawback can be an issue when Normal-types are potentially around, but its great coverage still makes it good way to clean teams.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: Not only does this make Dragon Darts difficult to wall, but it clinches a OHKO on Breloom regardless of the item.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy makes setting up against Great Tusk and Dragon-types much more feasible.

  • Fire: Not only does this make Fairy-types easier to deal with, but it can help Dragapult sweep through defensive Steel-types such as Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Steel: Steel covers a lot of Dragapult's former weaknesses, letting it set up on new foes such as Mimikyu.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing into a Ghost-type gives Dragapult the option for a much more reliable STAB move in Tera Blast, at the cost of not helping it set up against new threats.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is far less likely to stop Dragapult's sweep.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• Despite the lower offensive stat, the higher base power of Dragapult's special attacks makes it a serious threat.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is the recommended coverage move for hitting Corviknight and Dondozo hard.

  • U-turn: Even though it's weak, U-turn is a reasonable consideration for pivoting and breaking Mimikyu's Disguise.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: The stronger Shadow Ball makes this Dragapult difficult to wall outside of Normal-types and Ghost resistant foes such as Garganacl.

  • Fire: The Fairy-type resistance and powerful Flamethrower can make the Stealth Rock weakness worth it.

  • Fighting: The resistance to Sucker Punch Tera Fighting provides can be key in stopping Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Dragapult's match-up against other Dragon-types and Great Tusk.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon makes Draco Meteor nearly impossible to wall without a resistance.

sets.name: Bulky Status
sets.description:
• With usable bulk bolstered by Will-O-Wisp, this Dragapult can severely punish its weaker offensive checks.

  • Disable and Substitute: Disable makes Dragapult rely on Will-O-Wisp for Normal-types, but when combined with Substitute, it defeats Choice-locked foes and those that rely on one specific move to beat Dragapult.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor improves Dragapult against other Dragon-types, particularly Hydreigon and itself.

  • Flamethrower: This lets Dragapult deal decent unconditional damage to Steel-types, with Kingambit being the biggest target.

  • Dragon Darts: With a Naive nature, Dragon Darts gives Dragapult a consequence-free Dragon-type attack and decent mixed attacking potential.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Dragapult preforms better against most Dragon-types and Knock Off users such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant.

  • Steel: Steel Tera type is great for general defense and Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Mimikyu.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Dragapult's high Speed combined with Reflect and Light Screen make it an effective dual screens lead.

  • Curse: Curse reduces Dragapult's HP to get it off the field quickly once it has set up screens. It also forces opponents to use recovery moves or switch out, allowing Dragapult's teammates to get in and set up safely. Curse is Dragapult’s best option to bypass Substitute, Protect, and Mimikyu.

  • Shadow Ball: This breaks Focus Sash, hits Ghosts like Gholdengo and opposing Dragapult that normally threaten it, and breaks Mimikyu's Disguise. Notably Gholdengo stops Curse with Good as Gold, making Dragapult totally helpless against it if it does not carry Shadow Ball.

  • Dragon Darts: Dragon Darts can be used for more power to make Dragapult more self-sufficient when it has to stay on the field, and breaks Focus Sash as well. Its dual-hit nature makes it bypass most Substitutes.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple physical attackers. In tandem with Reflect, this can be a potent strategy to allow the next Pokemon to set up nearly risk-free.

Tera Types

  • Ghost / Dragon: Dragapult, as a screens supporter, should not normally Terastallize, but if you are in a bad spot, Ghost and Dragon power up its STAB move of choice.

  • Steel: A defensive typing like Steel can allow Dragapult to survive certain moves like Iron Bundle's Ice Beam, boosted Cloyster's Icicle Spear, and boosted Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and retaliate.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type is useful for enemy Infiltrator Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

Items

  • Focus Sash: While Light Clay is standard, Focus Sash nearly guarantees setting at least one screen without having to Terastallize, in the event Dragapult leads off against Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada.

Meowscarada.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: CRITTY CAT
sets.description:
• With its good Attack, Speed, and access to Flower Trick and Knock Off, Meowscarada is a potent cleaner that is also hard to switch into.

  • Flower Trick: With its guaranteed critical hit, Flower Trick is a dangerous cleaning move once resistances to it have been sufficiently chipped.

  • Trick: Trick can help Choice-locked sets incapacitate an annoying wall, such as Dondozo or Amoonguss, by locking them into a single move. Make sure to use a neutral nature and use a Jolly Mint on Meowscarada, so it won't get confused by eating any Berry after Trick.

  • Low Kick: Low Kick OHKOs Hydreigon, Roaring Moon, and Kingambit if using Protean.

Abilities

  • Protean: Protean’s type-shifting allows Meowscarada to make the most of its colorful movepool, particularly on Choice-locked sets, where the limitation to only changing types once is effectively nullified.

  • Overgrow: If you intend to make use of a Tera type other than Grass or switch moves often, Overgrow is worth considering, as it allows Meowscarada more flexibility with its moves by not changing type and removing STAB from Flower Trick or Knock Off.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band boosted Meowscarada hits incredibly hard, and with its naturally high Speed it can serve as a cleaner and a potential wallbreaker.

  • Choice Scarf: With the Speed offered via Choice Scarf, Meowscarada can threaten otherwise faster foes, such as Dragapult, potentially putting more pressure on offensive teams.

Tera Types

  • Grass: While Terastallizing does override Protean, Tera Grass Meowscarada can be used to power through teams ill-prepared for it. Dual screens teams in particular are especially vulnerable to the sheer power of Choice Band-boosted Tera Grass Flower Trick.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
• With its good Speed and wide movepool, Meowscarada makes for a potent lead.

  • Sucker Punch: Sucker Punch allows Meowscarada to better handle foes such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Toxic Spikes: Toxic Spikes’s forced passive damage is a great asset for the fast-paced teams Meowscarada generally finds itself on.

  • Taunt: Thanks to its good Speed, Meowscarada makes particularly excellent use of Taunt, shutting down other entry hazard leads such as Garchomp and Hippowdon.

  • Play Rough: This provides good coverage for Fighting- and Dragon-types that might otherwise pose issues, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Low Kick: Low Kick is worth considering if your team struggles with Kingambit.

  • Overgrow: Since this Meowscarada set aims to be more of a supportive Pokemon, Overgrow is preferred to keep STAB on its attacks after it uses its support moves.

Tera Types

  • Grass: When paired with an Overgrow boost, Tera Grass lets Flower Trick deal a huge amount of damage.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy eases Meowscarada's matchup against Choice Band Dragapult, who can threaten to KO through Focus Sash via Dragon Darts.

Skeledirge.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Defensive Gator
sets.description:
• Thanks to instant recovery, Unaware, and the snowballing potential of Torch Song, Skeledirge distinguishes itself as one of the premier physical walls.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Yawn: Will-O-Wisp vastly improves Skeledirge's match-up against fearsome physical foes such as Kingambit, while Yawn works exceptionally well with Stealth Rock support.

  • Substitute: Substitute is a good way around status, especially Garganacl's Salt Cure. It also becomes effective when used on Toxic Spikes teams.

Other Options

  • Encore: When paired with Substitute, Skeledirge can seriously punish passive Pokemon, though at a serious cost in coverage.

  • Flame Charge: Despite Skeledirge's low Speed, stacking Flame Charge boosts can make it difficult to check, though it'll often need multiple boosts to outspeed threats without compromising its bulk.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Terastallizing into the Fairy typing removes Skeledirges glaring weakness to Dark and provides an overall superior defensive typing. It also provides a neutral typing for the inevitable Shadow Balls that will be thrown at Skeledirge. With proper timing, Skeledirge can defeat counters meant to deal with it, most notably Gholdengo and Dragapult.

  • Normal: While Tera Normal isn't fantastic defensively, it lets Skeledirge severely punish attempts from special attacking Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult to check it.

  • Water: A Water Tera type lets Skeledirge take on formerly super effective attacks such as Liquidation, providing a valuable turn to burn the offender. It should be noted that Tera Water tends to be a safer option versus the ubiquitous Gholdengo, as it does not often run Thunderbolt.

Items

  • Leftovers or Sitrus Berry: The residual recovery helps Skeledirge use Torch Song more freely.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak ignores the secondary effects of Salt Cure and Acid Spray, improving Skeledirge's match-up against Garganacl and Bellibolt.

Safety Goggles: The immunity to Spore Skeledirge gains lets it check Breloom and Brute Bonnet far more effectively.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This makes Skeledirge less pressured to Terastallize to rid itself of its Stealth Rock weakness.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Bold: The EVs are set to maximize physical bulk with just enough Speed to outpace uninvested Corviknight.

  • 220 HP / 164 Def / 4 SpA / 108 SpD / 12 Spe with Calm: This EV spread allows both Tera Fairy and Water Skeledirge to avoid a 2HKO from a plethora of offensive threats, such as Modest Gholdengo, Adamant Azumarill, and Choice Specs Dragapult, while still boasting significant physical bulk.

sets.name: Blunder Song
sets.description:
This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

EV Spreads

  • 164 HP / 180 SpA / 164 Spe with Modest: This EV spread outspeeds Dragapult after gaining +2 Speed.

  • 252 HP / 92 Def / 164 Spe with Bold: This more defensive EV spread outspeeds Dragapult at +2 Speed.

sets.name: Offensive Gator
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

Quaquaval.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulky
sets.description:
• While Quaquaval's bulk is only serviceable, having both Roost and a great support movepool makes it a reasonable defensive option that does particularly well against Kingambit.

  • Taunt and Bulk Up: Taunt pairs particularly well with Bulk Up, letting it set up on surprising foes such as Corviknight.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Quaquaval stall out OHKO moves from the likes of Dondozo, and it protects it from Garganacl's Salt Cure.

  • Encore: Not only does Encore give Quaquaval new chances to set up, but it also punishes passive play from Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Flying: While it has very little defensive synergy with Quaquaval's previous typing, Tera Flying lets Quaquaval effectively stall out Dondozo if using Taunt, or Substitute and Encore together.

  • Grass: Tera Grass makes Quaquaval's match-up against Rotom-W much smoother.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Quauqaval a better matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, who can be fairly problematic otherwise.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Quaquaval can set up against most defensive Garchomp thanks to the Dragon Tail immunity.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet pairs well with Taunt and Tera Flying, letting Quaquaval easily play around Dondozo and Corviknight while setting up Bulk Up.

  • Covert Cloak: If running Substitute isn't possible, Covert Cloak is Quaquaval's best shot at defeating Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 SpD / 100 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread allows Quaquaval to outspeed Meowscarada while raising its special bulk. If not using Bulk Up, running Defense EVs is also viable instead.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 76 Def / 116 SpD / 68 Spe with Careful: The Special Defense investment and Careful nature let Quaquaval survive Choice Specs Hydreigon's Draco Meteor at full health, and the Speed lets it outspeed Garchomp after Aqua Step. The Defense investment lets Quaquaval avoid a 2HKO from Tera Dark Black Glasses Kingambit with one Supreme Overlord boost.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed ensures that Quaquaval outspeeds Choice Scarf Gholdengo, Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult after using Aqua Step.

sets.name: Moxie Sweeper
sets.description:
• Aqua Step and Moxie give Quaquaval a niche as a late-game sweeper that doesn't always need a turn of setup.

  • Ice Spinner: This is Quaquaval's best way of dealing big damage to Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Encore: Encore lets Quaquaval punish slower foes such as Corviknight by getting an easy setup opportunity.

  • Roost: Recovery might seem odd on such an offensive Pokemon, but it helps Quaquaval avoid getting worn down against bulkier teams.

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet's ability to pick off weakened threats pairs very well with Moxie, giving it new potential win conditions.

Tera Types

  • Water: Boosting Aqua Step's power opens up new sweeping chances late-game.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Quaquaval deal massive damage to Azumarill and wear down Dondozo switch-ins with Tera Blast.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Quaquaval potentially set up against would-be checks such as Rotom-W.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Quaquaval can get around Will-O-Wisp.

Items

  • Life Orb: The power increase makes sweeping with Aqua Step easier, especially against bulkier foes.

  • Focus Sash: With Focus Sash, Quaquaval trades potential wallbreaking for getting surprise sweeps against more offensive teams.

Lokix.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Tinted Offense
sets.description:
• The combination of First Impression and Tinted Lens make Lokix one of the most threatening revenge killers in the format, able to outprioritize and KO foes regardless of resistance.

  • First Impression is Lokix's most important attack, but it can only be used as the first attack after it switches in.

  • U-turn can be punishing against offensive and slow teams as the lack of resists means Lokix can keep switching in and dealing big damage with First Impression, at the cost of making it vulnerable to hazards.

  • Leech Life is the strongest Bug-type move Lokix learns outside of First Impression, with the added benefit of healing recoil damage.

  • Sucker Punch is a powerful STAB priority move, enabling Lokix to outprioritize foes even after it has used First Impression.

  • Axe Kick is the only coverage move of note in Lokix's moveset due to its high Base Power. Be wary of the low accuracy and recoil that occurs should it miss.

  • Throat Chop is the most powerful Dark-type move Lokix learns. It also has the side benefit of disabling Roar from Hippowdon and Hyper Voice from Sylveon.

  • Swords Dance is an option to make Lokix a sweeper instead of a revenge killer.

Items

Life Orb: Life Orb enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

Silver Powder: Silver Powder raises the power of First Impression without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Tera Types

Bug: A Bug Tera Type increases the damage of First Impression, allowing Lokix to OHKO foes it could not otherwise, such as Dragapult.

Pawmot.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
• Pawmot separates itself from Iron Hands by having an excellent support movepool and a good Speed tier.

  • Double Shock and Close Combat: Double Shock and Close Combat are its most important attacks, but note that it can only use Double Shock once without Terastallizing. Once Terastillized, Pawmot you can use Double Shock continuously for big damage, even on foes that resist it.

  • Mach Punch: Priority allows Pawmot to revenge kill better, hitting Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Iron Bundle super effectively.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Pawmot coverage against Ground-types, most notably Clodsire and Garchomp, in addition to hitting Dragapult for lots of damage.

  • Revival Blessing: Revival Blessing's one shot of reviving a teammate give Pawmot an extremely unique niche in turning battles around, though it doesn't fit all offensive teams.

  • Nuzzle This is notably one of the few ways to inflict paralysis on Gholdengo. Nuzzle is best when used with a Focus Sash, as Pawmot can paralyze the foe and outspeed it the next turn, getting another move off before it faints.

  • Encore: Encore does a great job of punishing passive play, and prevents easy setup from slower defensive foes such as Garganacl.

Other Options

  • Fake Out: This can be used to get an edge against common Focus Sash leads such as Meowscarada.

Abilities

  • Iron Fist: This boosts the power of Mach Punch and Ice Punch, giving Pawmot more powerful priority and coverage.

  • Volt Absorb: Volt Absorb's Electric immunity stops Magnezone, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H from using Volt Switch to create safe switch-ins.

  • Natural Cure: This allows Pawmot to take status moves more freely, such as Yawn from Dondozo or Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge.

Items

  • Life Orb: Life Orbs enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash trades the damage boost from the other items for better opportunities to use support moves.

  • Magnet: Magnet will power up Double Shock without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Tera Types

  • Electric: An Electric Tera Type allows Pawmot to continuously use Double Shock, making it an effective late-game cleaner.

Garganacl.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• With Purifying Salt making it immune to status and Salt Cure providing useful chip damage, especially against Water- and Steel-types, Garganacl is a dangerous defensive setup Pokemon.

  • Iron Defense and Body Press: Body Press is the best option for consistency against offensive teams.

  • Fissure: Fissure severely punishes passive play against Garganacl, at the cost of forcing it to rely on Salt Cure residual damage against offensive teams.

  • Curse and Earthquake: While Curse is slower to set up than Iron Defense, it can be paired with Earthquake to potentially defeat Substitute Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Flying: A Flying typing lets Garganacl take on new foes such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Ghost: A Ghost Tera type gives Garganacl an immunity to Body Press, giving it the edge against Corviknight and opposing Garganacl, especially when paired with Leftovers. Note that Curse will no longer boost Garganacl's stats when Terastallized.

  • Water: Tera Water vastly improves Garganacl's chances of defeating Gholdengo, thanks to the Make It Rain resist.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type stops Amoonguss from clearing its boosts with Clear Smog and makes Garganacl a decent check to Fairy-types such as offensive Mimikyu and Substitute + Calm Mind Flutter Mane.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: If using Tera Flying Garganacl, maximizing Special Defense is the best choice for easier setup.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: In addition to powering up Body Press, a focus on Defense makes setting up on powerful setup sweepers such as Dragonite an easier task.

  • 252 HP / 84 Def / 172 SpD with Careful: This EV spread allows Tera Steel Garganacl to avoid a 2HKO from Breloom's Mach Punch after Iron Defense.

sets.name: Salty Stall
sets.description:
• With some entry hazard support, this Garganacl can be very difficult to outstall, thanks to the constant passive damage from Salt Cure.

  • Protect: Not only does Protect scout for surprise Tera types, but it also goes well with the passive healing from Leftovers.

  • Substitute: This makes Garganacl even more difficult to properly switch into, providing protection against Trick, OHKO moves, and opposing Salt Cure.

  • Fissure: Garganacl's great bulk makes it a prime candidate for fishing with Fissure itself, though its low PP can be an issue in mirror matches.

  • Stealth Rock: Since this set benefits so much from Stealth Rock support, running it on its own is a reasonable sacrifice if Garganacl needs to be more self-sufficient.

Other Options

  • Fling with Light Ball, Toxic Orb, or Flame Orb: Although the loss of Leftovers can be a huge blow for Garganacl, Fling and its associated status inducing items can be a devastating surprise for some of its offensive checks, such as Great Tusk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying gets rid of the Ground and Fighting weaknesses, giving it a far better chance of beating Great Tusk and Garchomp. It also makes Fissure no longer an issue.

  • Ghost: While removing Purifying Salt's Ghost resistance is a shame, Tera Ghost does wonderfully against Corviknight, Great Tusk, and opposing Garganacl due to the Body Press immunity.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy makes taking on powerful Dragon-types such as Garchomp and Roaring Moon an easier task.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Garganacl a better matchup against Gholdengo and Flutter Mane.

  • Grass: Tera Grass gives Garganacl a much easier time against Rotom-W and Palafin-H.

Armarouge.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Expanding Force
sets.description:
• Armarouge's combination of powerful STAB moves, excellent coverage, Weak Armor, and Psychic Terrain makes it strong candidate to use Focus Sash.

  • Psychic Terrain Psychic Terrain is a powerful setup move for Armarouge thanks to Expanding Force; it also protects Armarouge from priority moves after Weak Armor triggers.

  • Expanding Force: Expanding Force under Psychic Terrain, especially with Tera Psychic, is a devastatingly powerful move.

  • Armor Cannon: This helps Armarouge defeat Steel-types that resist Expanding Force.

  • Aura Sphere: Aura Sphere is excellent coverage against the Dark-types.

  • Destiny Bond: This is a good alternative to forcefully take down threats that Armarouge can’t easily KO.

  • Energy Ball: Energy Ball hits the specially defensive Water-types Armarouge might struggle to defeat otherwise, most notably Gastrodon.

Tera Types

  • Psychic: With a boost from Tera Psychic, Expanding Force OHKOes even relatively bulky foes such as Garchomp and Flutter Mane. With Stealth Rock, Expanding Force still achieves most notable KOs without Tera Psychic, but the extra damage is still appreciated.

  • Fighting: In cases where setting up Psychic Terrain proves to be more difficult, Tera Fighting provides a useful resistance to Sucker Punch and powers up Aura Sphere.

Ceruledge.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulk Up Sweeper
sets.description:
• Bulk Up Ceruledge makes excellent use of both its respectable bulk and Bitter Blade's high recovery. By changing its typing to a more defense oriented one, while maintaining the Fire immunity thanks to Flash Fire, Ceruledge can set up Bulk Ups on a variety of common Pokemon, ranging from Corviknight, Kingambit, Azumarill and Gholdengo.

  • Taunt: Taunt lets Ceruledge set up Bulk Up without needing to fear common phasing moves (with the exception of attacking moves such as Dragon Tail), as well as opposing setup moves such opposing Bulk Up and Iron Defense, provided you outspeed.

  • Shadow Sneak Priority of some form is always nice to have on a Pokemon, which makes Shadow Sneak an easy contender for the last move. Gaining extra added strength against Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Dragapult and Annihilape is certainly charming.

  • Grass Tera Blast: This allows Ceruledge to eliminate Dondozo more quickly. While Taunt can shut down Dondozo's Yawn, it cannot shut down Fissure. The only way to beat Dondozo would be to eliminate it as quickly as possibly, which Grass Tera Blast aids with.

  • Flame Charge: Flame Charge provides Ceruledge an extra net of safety against potential Scarf users and Annihilape, who are capable of turning the tides against it. While normally, Ceruledge is prone to faster Taunt + Bulk Up users and Scarfed Trick, Flame Charge helps mitigate both of those weaknesses.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Ceruledge can be a status spreader in games where it can't set up as easily. It also helps Ceruledge set up more easily against threats such as Unaware Clodsire.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy helps Ceruledge's matchup against prominent Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Hydreigon.

  • Grass: An immunity to Spore and a resistance to Water makes Grass the most notable Tera type for this set. Flash Fire eliminating one of Grass's many weaknesses is also noteworthy.

  • Fire: Increasing Bitter Blade's power will always be a valuable trait. Eliminating Ghost's weaknesses to Ghost and Dark also allows Ceruledge to set up more comfortably.

  • Bug: Tera Bug is similar to Tera Grass, but in exchange for losing the Water resistance and maintaining the Rock weakness of Fire / Ghost, Ceruledge can tank Volcarona's Bug Buzz with significantly more ease.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def with Impish: Investing into Defense prepares Ceruledge and its mediocre physical bulk for the physical-biased metagame. Bulk Up will boost its Defense, but it can struggle to take some physical hits even after a boost, and its special bulk is naturally high.

  • 252 HP / 252 Spe with Jolly: A faster spread helps Ceruledge outspeed other Bulk Up users, like Annihilape opting to invest in bulk. Being faster, more often than not, lets Ceruledge win these matchups with ease.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD with Careful: While most threats in the metagame at the moment are physical, a specially defensive spread is still noteworthy for its ability to surprise Hydreigon.

sets.name: Focus Sash Attacker
sets.description:
• With a stellar offensive typing, a unique set of attacks, Weak Armor allowing it to outspeed a large part of the metagame, and its immunity to Extreme Speed and Mach Punch, Ceruledge proves itself to be a very solid Focus Sash option.

  • Bitter Blade: Bitter Blade's recovery can make Focus Sash usable even if entry hazards chip it. If Ceruledge is brought down to 1 HP, a +2 Bitter Blade can heal it to the point that it can tank an extra attack.

  • Close Combat versus Shadow Claw: Close Combat hits the Normal-, Dark-, and Rock-types that resist Ceruledge's STAB combination. Still, Shadow Claw is a noteworthy choice to guarantee the KO on Mimikyu and let Ceruledge pressure Skeledirge. Note, however, that maximum Defense Skeledirge can recover more than Shadow Claw's damage, barring critical hits, and a Terastallized Skeledirge can completely wall this set.

  • Swords Dance versus Destiny Bond: As powerful as Swords Dance boosted attacks from Ceruledge are, the abundance of Unaware Pokemon, primarily Dondozo, has made some players opt to use Destiny Bond to attempt Dondozo—makes Destiny Bond viable to snag surprise kills. KOs. Destiny Bond can also make the matchup against KOing common Sucker Punch Pokemon, such as Meowscarada and Kingambit, easier to win without having to rely on predictions. less prediction reliant.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: Adamant's added damage output is valuable, but Jolly allows Ceruledge to outspeed non-Scarf Gholdengo, and gives it a chance at outspeeding Modest Rotom formes and Glimmora. All of the mentioned examples are Special Attackers, meaning Ceruledge's Weak Armor often does not trigger in these matchups.

Tera Types

  • Fire: Giving Bitter Blade an extra push in damage is quite useful, giving Ceruledge more recovery.

  • Normal: Normal is an exceedingly common Tera Type on Ghost types due to the immunity it brings to the table. Ceruledge makes particularly excellent use of Normal Tera by resisting both Steel and Fairy, making it very difficult for Gholdengo and Mimikyu to click anything other than a Ghost type move when facing off against Ceruledge.

  • Fighting: Giving extra reach pwer to Close Combat, a powerful option against Pokemon such as Hydreigon, makes Fighting a solid choice for a Tera Type.

Bellibolt.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Fat Bellibolt
sets.description:
• Bellibolt's stats allow it to be deceptively bulky, and a pure Electric typing is not terrible on a defensive Pokemon with reliable recovery and pivoting.

  • Parabolic Charge: Parabolic Charge gives Bellibolt a more constant stream of recovery, though it is much less punishing than Discharge.

  • Volt Switch: Volt Switch maintains initiative when predicting switches after bringing Bellibolt in on something that it walls, such as defensive Gholdengo or Corviknight.

  • Chilling Water: Chilling Water punishes Garchomp and Hippowdon on the switch-in.

  • Thunder Wave: This disrupts opponents if Bellibolt doesn't have Discharge.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: Tera Blast hits common Dragon-types such as Garchomp and Baxcaliber after Terastallizing into the Fairy typing.

  • Soak: Soak catches Electric resistant foes on the switch-in and forces them to either switch out or Terastallize early, with major targets including Garchomp and Baxcalibur.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Terastallizing into the Grass typing flips the matchup against Ground-types on its head, turning their attacks from super effective into a resisted hit while still charging Bellibolt's next Electric hit; this allows Bellibolt to wall Hippowdon and Garchomp and absorb Spores vs Breloom and Amoonguss, effectively walling them as well.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type comfortably walls Dragon-types, removing a lot of their offensive pressure.

  • Water: Water is just generally good to have as a defensive Tera type. It also gives Bellibolt STAB on Chilling Water for slightly more damage.

EV Spreads

  • 228 HP / 244 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 28 Spe: This EV spread allows Bellibolt to live two Glaive Rushes from Adamant Baxcalibur if it is not in a position to Terastallize. The physical bulk lets Bellibolt always survive Life Orb Garchomp's Earthquake, and after Terastallization into a neutral type, it becomes a 3HKO. 28 Speed EVs allow Bellibolt to outspeed 4 Speed Hippowdon.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers provides long term passive recovery alongside Slack Off, which can make Bellibolt very difficult to remove. Leftovers also removes any chance of a 2HKO from powerful physical threats such as Baxcalibur.

  • Sitrus Berry: A short-term HP booster that effectively gives Bellibolt 125% HP, making it a good back-up option if Leftovers is already in use.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet Bellibolt can switch into and punish physical attackers in a more passive manner; the chip damage can also break Focus Sash and weaken things into range of Electromorphosis-boosted attacks.

sets.name: Tactical Bellibolt
sets.description:
• Bellibolt can be quite unassuming, and specially offensive Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Rotom may see it as a free opportunity to get into position. Assault Vest turns the tides against them with Electromorphosis + Parabolic Charge, which makes Bellibolt seem impossible to remove for certain Pokemon. It's also a decent check against Iron Bundle.

  • Grass or Fairy Tera Blast: Tera Blast is important coverage to have; with a Fairy Tera type, Bellibolt reliably checks non-Tera Steel Dragons.

  • Muddy Water versus Chilling Water: Muddy Water should be used with Tera Electric for much-needed coverage. Alternatively, Chilling Water weakens common switch-ins such as Garchomp and Baxcalibur, allowing you to reposition your team more safely.

  • Acid Spray: This threatens non-Steel type switch-ins and also allows Bellibolt to effectively use it’s ability without having to take damage first. Its also a powerful tool against Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

  • Sucker Punch: While weak, Sucker Punch catches Focus Sash Pokemon and/or deals chip damage on turns where Bellibolt is guaranteed to go down.

Tera Types

  • Fairy-type: Fairy Tera Bellibolt offensively checks big threats like Roaring Moon and Dragapult by walling their non-Tera sets and nabbing surprise KOes.

  • Grass-type: Grass Tera Bellibolt can stay in versus common Pokemon such as Hippowdon can Breloom, sponge their attacks, and either chunk them or survive and reposition.

  • Electric-type: Maximizing Parabolic Charge damage is a viable option.

EV Spreads

  • 228 HP / 28 Def / 180 SpA / 44 SpD / 28 Spe: This spread is to avoid the 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Rotom-W and Hydreigon's Hydro Pump and Draco Meteor, respectively. 28 Speed EVs allow Bellibolt to outspeed 4 Speed Hippowdon. 28 Defense EVs are enough for Bellibolt to survive Focus Sash Garchomp's Earthquake, which notably becomes a 3HKO if Bellibolt Terastallizes into into a typing without a weakness to Ground.

sets.name: Bespectacled Bellibolt
sets.description:
• With such good natural bulk, Bellibolt can easily survive hits from common threats and nab surprise KO's in return with a cheeky Choice Specs set.

  • Discharge / Thunderbolt: Discharge or Thunderbolt is the preferred primary STAB move, as either one takes advantage of Choice Specs more than Parabolic Charge. With an Electromorphosis boost, Bellibolt can 2HKO common switch-ins without having to Terastallize, like Dragapult.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: Tera Blast is important for coverage; with a Fairy typing you reliably check non-Tera Steel Dragons. Muddy Water should be used with Tera Electric.

  • Muddy Water versus Parabolic Charge: Muddy Water lets Bellibolt win the one-on-one against Hippowdon. Parabolic Charge should be used if run Tera Electric with Muddy Water already available in a different moveslot.

Tera Types

  • Fairy-type: Tera Fairy let Bellibolt turn the tables on bulky Dragon-types such as Baxcalibur and Roaring Moon by scoring a surprise KO on a potential setup attempt.

  • Grass-type: Tera Grass turns Bellibolt's only weakness into a resistance and gets surprise OHKOs on threats such as physically defensive Hippowdon.

  • Electric-type: Tera Electric + Choice Specs turns Bellibolt into an offensive behemoth, and with an Electromorphosis boost it can OHKO resists like Dragapult, Hydreigon, and specially defensive Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 228 HP / 28 Def / 196 SpA / 28 SpD / 28 Spe: This EV spread allows Bellibolt to survive Choice Specs Draco Meteor from Hydreigon and Earthquake from Focus Sash Garchomp; Garchomp's Earthquake becomes a 3HKO if Bellibolt Terastallizes into a typing without a weakness to Ground. The Speed EVs outspeed 4 Speed Hippowdon, while the SpA EVs are enough to OHKO physically defensive Hippowdon with Muddy Water.

Scovillain.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Sun Attacker
sets.description:
• Tera Fire Scovillain's damage under sun is absurd, managing to barely KO even Fire-resistant targets. Most notably, its ability to defeat most Pokemon, even powerful Dragon-types, without fearing surprise Terastallizations makes Scovillain a charming offensive option.

  • Overheat and Fire Blast: Overheat combined with Tera Fire and Choice Specs guarantees the KO on Garchomp without bulk EVs, and OHKO offensive Roaring Moon after Stealth Rock damage. Against the frailer Dragapult, Tera Fire and Fire Blast is enough to earn the KO. It's recommended to run both Fire STAB moves because Overheat's added damage can be necessary to guarantee certain KOs, but its stat drop can be fatal.

  • Solar Beam versus Leaf Storm: Solar Beam nails the few bulky Water-types that can survive Scovillain's absurd attacks, most notable examples being notably Gastrodon and Assault Vest Azumarill. However, Leaf Storm can be used in its stead for the ability to OHKO Hippowdon, despite it summoning sand.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower is perfectly accurateand is typically more than enough to nip off frailer foes.

  • Substitute: In spite of the type matchup, Scovillain is deceptively weak to Kingambit thanks to Sucker Punch. Additionally, many Pokemon will use Protect in front of Scovillain to waste sun turns— most notably Espathra and Dondozo. Against all of these foes, a well-timed Substitute can guarantee the win.

Tera Types

  • Fire: It is almost mandatory to run Tera Fire on this Scovillain set. Tera Fire guarantees KOs on most Dragon-types.

  • Ghost: The abundantly common Dragonite is incredibly strong against Scovillain. Should Stealth Rock support be deemed enough to let Scovillain sweep teams reasonably, even without Tera Fire, using Tera Ghost to gain an immunity to Extreme Speed can be very useful.

  • Rock: Tera Rock with Tera Blast can be a decent alternative to Tera Fire, as it gives Scovillain excellent coverage and also provides a much-needed countermeasure to Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Moody Ace
sets.description:
• The metagame's abundance of Unaware Pokemon makes it difficult to maneuver Moody Pokemon in general. On top of that, Scovillain is held back by the powerful Dragon-types that resist its STAB combination. However, Scovillain still carves a niche for itself by being the only Moody Pokemon with excellent recovery moves, Leech Seed and Ingrain, allowing it to win a variety of matchups.

  • Protect and Substitute: Protect and Substitute are mandatory to get the most opportunities to activate Moody. Once you gain enough Defense or Special Defense boosts that Scovillain's Substitute can tank an attack without breaking, it tends to be easy to win the game. Note, however, that Protect, Substitute, and Leftovers's animation make Scovillain very vulnerable to losing via timer.

  • Flamethrower: With enough Moody boosts, Scovillain's Flamethrower tends to be enough to break through an entire team. There are very few Pokemon that are immune or quadruply resistant to Fire, and Flamethrower has good PP and accuracy, which makes it an easy pick.

  • Giga Drain: Unlike Flamethrower, Giga Drain gets shrugged off by a lot of Pokemon, even at +6, notably Corviknight and Dragonite. However, an attacking move that helps recover HP lost from Substitutes helps it gain gives Scovillain more mileage off of Moody. Giga Drain is also notable to more reliably defeat Dondozo, one of the Unaware Pokemon that would give Scovillain a lot of trouble otherwise.

  • Leech Seed: Leech Seed combined with Protect, Substitute, and Leftovers helps Scovillain restore HP while collecting Moody boosts, as well as chipping Pokemon it'd otherwise have trouble against, such as Clodsire.

  • Ingrain: Ingrain is an alternative recovery option that makes Scovillain impervious to phazing moves. When purely considering recovery, it's more reliable than the inaccurate 90% accurate Leech Seed.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: Tera Blast with Tera Fairy is an excellent option that helps remedy Scovillain's Dragon susceptibility, particularly making the Infiltrator Dragapult and Roaring Moon matchup easier.

Tera Types

  • Water: The Water resistance helps Scovillain beat Dondozo. Even though Dondozo ignores Scovillain's Defense boosts via Unaware, with Tera Water, Scovillain's Substitute can tank a Wave Crash. Tera Water also keeps the Scovillain's Steel resistance, unlike Tera Grass, which makes it easier to check Scizor—a common priority user that people attempt to use to check Moody Pokemon.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy mitigating Scovillain's weakness to Dragon-types is massively helpful.

EV Spreads

  • 180 HP / 220 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 100 Spe with Bold: This spread bolsters Scovillain’s physical bulk. Notably, Tera Water Scovillain's Substitute manages to survive Dondozo's Wave Crash with this spread. The Speed allows Scovillain to outspeed slow Baxcalibur and Gholdengo, as well as Dragapult with one Moody Speed boost. The HP is adjusted to make maximum use of Leftovers, with the resulting stat having a remainder of 1 when divided by 16. The remaining EVs are split between Special Attack and Special Defense because, at level 50, investing 8 EVs in either stat has no benefit over investing 4.

Espathra.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Speed Passer
sets.description:
• Espathra is the only option for the coveted Speed Boost + Baton Pass combination, which can be extremely deadly for setting up sweeps!

  • Lumina Crash: Lumina Crash ensures that Espathra isn't totally shut down by Taunt, and the guaranteed -2 Special Defense drop helps against Unaware walls.

  • Hypnosis: While extremely risky, putting a foe to sleep lets Espathra easily stack up on boosts.

  • Some Teammates: While most Pokemon love getting Baton Pass boosts, especially consider Pokemon that resist Espathra's common weaknesses, such as Hydreigon, Roaring Moon Sylveon, and Kingambit. Corviknight is also worth considering due to Power Trip.

  • EV Spread: The given EV spread outspeeds Choice Scarf Hydreigon after one turn of Speed Boost.

Tera Types

  • Espathra should usually avoid Terastallizing if possible, since its point is to help other Pokemon sweep. Consider these two options as fairly situational.

  • Normal: With a Normal Tera type, Espartha can set up against its Ghost types and isn't worried about Shadow Sneak anymore.

  • Ghost: Ghost Tera type makes Espartha immune to Extreme Speed, making passing against Dragonite much easier.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is the best way to guarantee passing at least one Speed boost, though it's a lackluster option for passing multiple boosts compared to other items.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is the easy option to recommend since it pairs well with Protect and Substitute.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry should be used if Espathra is planning on passing Speed to teammates that want Leftovers, such as Skeledirge and Garganacl.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
• With Calm Mind and Speed Boost rapidly increasing Stored Power's damage output, Espathra is a dangerous wincon against bulkier teams, as it even overwhelms Unaware foes.

  • Dazzling Gleam: This provides coverage against Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Hydreigon.

  • Protect versus Substitute: Protect is the most reliable way to get a free turn of Speed Boost. Substitute is a riskier option for Speed Boost stalling, but it severely punishes passive Pokemon and works extremely well on dual screen teams.

  • EV Spread: The given EV spread allows Espathra to outspeed Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle after one turn of Speed Boost.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: When paired with Tera Blast, Tera Fighting is Espathra's only hope of defeating Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Fairy Tera type makes setting up on Hydreigon a much more realistic scenario and severely punishes Choice-locked Dragon-types like Dragapult.

  • Dark: Tera Dark provides gives Espathra a valuable Shadow Sneak resistance and does a better shot of defeating weakened Gholdengo.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

Tinkaton.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Tinkaton boasts an impressive support movepool alongside a fantastic typing in Fairy / Steel.

  • Encore: Encore can open up opportunities for teammates, locking foes into status moves or attacks that a teammate resists.

  • Thunder Wave: With Mold Breaker, Tinkaton is capable of paralyzing Gholdengo and Garganacl with Thunder Wave.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Tera makes Tinkaton immune to Ground, which can be useful in avoiding Earthquake from the likes of Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Tera Ground Baxcalibur.

  • Fire: Fire Tera turns Tinkaton's Fire-type weakness into a resistance, allowing it to use Encore on Volcarona.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 164 Def / 20 SpD / 76 Spe with Careful: The HP and Defense investment lets Tinkaton survive Adamant Dragonite's Earthquake into Extreme Speed. The Special Defense investment allows Tinkaton to survive one Timid Choice Specs Fire Blast from Hydreigon, two Modest Choice Specs Shadow Balls from Dragapult, and three uninvested Shadow Balls from Gholdengo. The Speed investment allows Tinkaton to outspeed a paralyzed non-Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

Items

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon lets Tinkaton set up Stealth Rock against other common entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Glimmora without the use of Flying Tera and pairs incredibly well with Encore.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash allows Tinkaton to get a Thunder Wave off even against powerful attacks from the likes of Terastallized Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Dragapult.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description:
• Despite Tinkaton's low offensive stats, it can still perform as an offensive Pokemon thanks to Gigaton Hammer's enormous 160 Base Power and Swords Dance.

  • Encore: Encore is a fantastic support move, potentially locking foes into resisted moves after a switch-in or denying slower, bulkier foes their recovery moves for a few turns.

  • Play Rough versus Knock Off: Play Rough is Tinkaton's best option against Roaring Moon, and thanks to Mold Breaker, Tinkaton can hit Unaware Dondozo with boosted Play Rough. Meanwhile, Knock Off is Tinkaton's best attack against Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Tera turns Tinkaton's Ground-type weakness into an immunity, allowing it to use Encore on moves like Earthquake and Fissure from foes such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Dondozo.

  • Steel: Steel Tera capitalizes on Gigaton Hammer to make it deal as much damage as possible.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 236 Atk / 36 Def / 4 SpD / 228 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds Annihilape and allows Tinkaton to survive a +1 Dragon Claw + Normal Tera Extreme Speed from Dragonite after Terastallizing.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers has great synergy with Encore, allowing it to set up while healing off some of the damage from weak moves.

  • Focus Sash: Holding a Focus Sash guarantees that Tinkaton can get at least one move off even against super effective attacks aimed at it.

  • Air Balloon: With Air Balloon, Tinkaton can give Ground-type foes like Great Tusk and Hippowdon issues before even Terastallizing.

Palafin.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. sets.name: This looks like a job for Palafin
sets.description:
• Palafin's stats are middling, but after switching out once it will forme change into Palafin-H, which boasts the highest base Attack in the format, making it an effective wall breaker and revenge killer.

  • Jet Punch: With Jet Punch, Palafin-H becomes an excellent revenge killer, being able to take down important threats such as Flutter Mane, Iron Moth, and Great Tusk.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat is good coverage, hitting Rotom-W for neutral damage and covering Roaring Moon and Meowscarada.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: An Adamant nature increases the damage Wave Crash and Jet Punch inflict, making Palafin-H a more effective wall breaker and revenge killer. A Jolly nature enables Palafin-H to outspeed Mimikyu and Hydreigon.

Tera Types

  • Water: A Water Tera type boosts Jet Punch and Wave Crash, making Palafin-H a potent late-game cleaner.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type turns all of Palafin-H's weaknesses into resistances, giving it a favorable matchup against Rotom-W, and making it immune to Spore from Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

Orthworm.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Thanks to Earth Eater, Orthworm can wall sets of many physical Dragon-types like Garchomp and Baxcalibur.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: Heavy Slam can 2HKO offensive Dragapult, OHKOs Flutter Mane, and deals much more damage to Iron Valiant, while Iron Head is superior for Dragonite.

  • Rest and Chesto Berry: Rest is an option with Chesto Berry to heal Orthworm in a pinch, giving it better longevity.

  • Shed Tail: Shed Tail gives Orthworm use when IronPress isn't as effective. The surprise factor comes at the price of the reduced effectiveness of IronPress.

  • Substitute: Substitute stops Salt Cure damage from Garganacl and phazing from Garchomp's Dragon Tail.

Other Options

  • Earthquake is an option to hit Gholdengo, but it won't 2HKO, so Recover is still a problem.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry allows two uses of Shed Tail.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a consistent option, especially in conjunction with Substitute.

Tera Types

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a key Fighting resistance and single weakness and maintains a key resistance to Flower Trick, letting Orthworm preform better against Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy provides a Fighting resistance and Dragon immunity, turning Dragon Tail Garchomp into setup bait, and dealing with Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Roaring Moon.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: This EV spread makes Orthworm much less likely to be 2HKOd by Life Orb Dragapult.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread can be used to outspeed Adamant Kingambit and most Corviknight and Skeledirge. This can be very useful if using Shed Tail.

sets.name: Shed Tail Support
sets.description:
• Orthworm's good physical bulk and ability make it a great user of Shed Tail, and a reliable Stealth Rock user.

  • Body Press: Body Press has a good chance to OHKO offensive Meowscarada, and threatens Kingambit and Roaring Moon.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: A Steel-type STAB move helps hit some Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Flutter Mane, who are OHKOed by Heavy Slam, and deals massive damage to Iron Valiant. Iron Head is an alternative for heavy foes like Dragonite.

  • Spikes: Orthworm can also set Spikes, but this compromises its ability to pass Shed Tail.

  • A Special Teammate: Many Pokemon can benefit from Orthworm's Shed Tail. One example is Air Balloon Gholdengo, which puts a lot of pressure on defensive foes when behind a Substitute.

Tera Types

  • This Orthworm isn't usually meant to Terastalize, since that's better served by the teammates its passing a Substitute to.

  • Poison: Tera Poison leaves Orthworm with only one fairly rare weakness, and aiding it against former threats like Great Tusk and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Orthworm a Fighting resistance, as well as a way to absorb Garchomp's Dragon Tail while still staying in.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD: This spread maximizes Orthworm's physical bulk. Running a Speed IV of 0 may be tempting, but being outsped by bulky Brute Bonnet is risky.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread outspeeds Kingambit, and most Skeledirge and Corviknight. Outspeeding Kingambit and Corviknight prevents Taunt from stopping Shed Tail, and let's Orthworm bring in a teammate against Torch Song.

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 212 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and Jolly Brute Bonnet. Mach Punch still does a lot, but thanks to Sitrus Berry, Orthworm will have enough HP left to Shed Tail to a check or counter.
